Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/15/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include
the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of three Independent Living (IL) files did not have a quarterly updated contract
for one quarter.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/8/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/15/22
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the contract required by R
400.12510, continues to reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing expenditures.
One of three IL files did not have monthly budgets completed for four months.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/8/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/15/22
2

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of one special evaluations did not have documentation that a copy of the report
was sent to the foster parent.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she
has a right to have his or her written response included
as an attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of
this rule.
One of one special evaluations did not have documentation the foster parent was
informed of their right to submit a written response to the report.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Borrowed Bed- Foster Parents and the agency must sign the Foster
Parent Agency Agreement annually.
• Medical Passports- Must be updated for all youth quarterly, even if a
parent signature is not required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Dental exams- new licensing rule require a dental exam within 30 days of
the child's first birthday and every nine months thereafter.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
During this review period, the agency had one CAP, approved 7/15/22. The CAP
was the result of the 6/8/22 renewal evaluation. In that evaluation, the agency had
thirty-seven violations. During the current evaluation, only seven violations were
found. Although three of the seven violations were repeats, the agency has shown
significant improvement in several areas. The Chief Administrator reported
successful implementation of their CAP over the past year, and ongoing
commitment to improving in additional areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) assessment was reviewed and discussed on-site.
The CA reported significant staff turnover during this past year. Throughout that,
leadership remained focused on improving and maintaining compliance by
implementing several strategies to track timeframes, review deadlines with staff,
4

and develop solutions to barriers. Overall, the CA reports these efforts have
proven to be effective and will continue to be implemented.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff were relatively new to their positions.
Both staff reported feeling supported by their supervisors. Staff identified the
recent changes from MiSACWIS to CWLM, and the new licensing rules as
challenges they continue to work through. However, staff stated they receive
support and guidance as needed. Neither staff had any recommendation for areas
of improvement at the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency remains in the same location as the previous several years. The office
is a located in downtown Jackson. The building has sufficient space for staff and
clients to hold visits and meetings. There is adequate locking storage for all files
and protected information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
